cards.title: Promotion of Active Learning
cards.content: The main goal was to establish an interactive platform that enables individuals to immerse themselves in a journey of active learning, driven by hands-on exercises.

cards.title: Supporting Fellow Learners
cards.content: The core purpose was to offer a valuable hub for all those seeking effective, self-directed education, providing guidance and resources to diverse learners.

cards.title: Hands-On Coding
cards.content: Experience Lightning Network by typing and executing actual code with syntax highlighting

cards.title: Engaging Experience
cards.content: Our passion lies in creating an immersive, understandable learning journey.

cards.title: Igniting Curiosity
cards.content: By granting free access and content suitable for learners of varying proficiency levels, the ambition was to ignite curiosity and enthusiasm for continuous learning.

list.title: A Spectrum of Cool Subjects
list.content: Through our "type and execute code yourself" approach, you'll immerse yourself in practical and interactive learning. Engage with real-time exercises for a deeper understanding.

list.title: Hands-On Experience
list.content: LightningLearn offers a complete learning immersion. Engage in tasks, challenges, lessons, and quizzes that refine your Lightning Network skill

list.title: Real-time Practice Access
list.content: We offer the opportunity to work on real-time exercises and simulations. This allows you to directly apply your knowledge and experience Lightning Network in a secure environment.

implementations.title: Core Lightning (previously c-lightning)
implementations.content: is a lightweight, highly customizable and standard compliant implementation of the Lightning Network protocol.

implementations.title: Eclair
implementations.content: Eclair (French for Lightning) is a Scala implementation of the Lightning Network.

implementations.title: The Lightning Network Daemon
implementations.content: is a complete implementation of a Lightning Network node. lnd has several pluggable back-end chain services including btcd (a full-node), bitcoind, and neutrino (a new experimental light client)

steps.Step 2: Install the snapd package: sudo apt-get install snapd -y
steps.Step 3: Install the Bitcoin Core client using snap: sudo snap install bitcoin-core
steps.Step 4: Create symbolic links to access Bitcoin Core binaries: sudo ln -s /snap/bitcoin-core/current/bin/bitcoin{d,-cli} /usr/local/bin/
steps.Step 5: Clone the Lightning Network repository from GitHub: git clone https://github.com/ElementsProject/lightning.git
steps.Step 6: Update the system and install necessary packages for compilation: udo apt-get update sudo apt-get install -y autoconf automake build-essential git libtool libsqlite3-dev python3 python3-pip net-tools zlib1g-dev libsodium-dev gettext pip3 install --upgrade pip pip3 install --user poetry
steps.Step 8: Configure and compile the Lightning Network source code: cd lightning && ./configure --enable-developer && make -j7 && make install
steps.Step 9: Create a directory to store Bitcoin data: mkdir ~/.bitcoin
steps.Step 10: Run the script to start a Bitcoin regtest network: . contrib/startup_regtest.sh
steps.Step 11: Start the Lightning Network daemon with 2 nodes: start_ln 2
steps.Step 12: Generate 10 blocks in the Bitcoin regtest blockchain: bt-cli generatetoaddress 10 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 13: Get the balances of Bitcoin addresses: bt-cli getbalances
steps.Step 14: Get information about the Lightning Network node: l2-cli getinfo
steps.Step 15: Connect to the first Lightning Network node: l1-cli connect 027530d124566d735277cf74dd030b7ef6fba8f671e67ecd48075827989d977600@127.0.0.1:7272
steps.Step 16: List the connected peers of the first node: l1-cli listpeers
steps.Step 17: Get a new Bitcoin address: l1-cli newaddr
steps.Step 18: Send 1 BTC to the specified address: bt-cli sendtoaddress bcrt1qxlgkw57ue298lmtt4xpzstalgzzh8gmg3pgvke 1 btc
steps.Step 19: Generate 10 blocks to the specified Bitcoin Core address: bt-cli generatetoaddress 10 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 21: Send 0.0005 BTC to the specified address: bt-cli sendtoaddress bcrt1qhgh2e65ktgzl945fyx7ea2cj39m08d2e6gegse 0.0005 btc
steps.Step 22: Generate 10 blocks to a new Bitcoin address: bt-cli generatetoaddress 10 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 23: List funds for the second Lightning Network node: l2-cli listfunds
steps.Step 24: Get information about the second Lightning Network node: l2-cli getinfo
steps.Step 25: Fund a Lightning channel from the first node to the second node: l1-cli fundchannel 027530d124566d735277cf74dd030b7ef6fba8f671e67ecd48075827989d977600 500000sat
steps.Step 26: List channels for the first node: l1-cli listchannels
steps.Step 27: Generate 12 blocks to a new Bitcoin address: bt-cli generatetoaddress 12 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 28: List channels for the first node: l1-cli listchannels
steps.Step 29: Fund a Lightning channel from the second node to the first node: l2-cli fundchannel 0212e254cf5a6fd9074c40d0d86b95ada6576443ab4e275188e7a25bb920efc57e 20000sat
steps.Step 30: Generate 12 blocks to a new Bitcoin address: bt-cli generatetoaddress 12 $(bt-cli getnewaddress)
steps.Step 31: List channels for the second node: l2-cli listchannels
steps.Step 32: Create an invoice for the second node: l2-cli invoice 100sat payme 'payme'
steps.Step 33: Make a payment from the first node to the second node: l1-cli pay
steps.Step 34: Create an invoice for the first node: l1-cli invoice 100sat payme 'payme'
steps.Step 35: Make a payment from the second node to the first node: l2-cli pay
steps.Step 36: List funds for the first node: l1-cli listfunds
steps.Step 37: List funds for the second node: l2-cli listfunds
steps.Step 38: List channels for the first node: l1-cli listchannels
steps.Step 39: List channels for the second node: l2-cli listchannels
